awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding Economic Growth: Firms, Inventors, and Ideas
awd_abstract_narration:
The main focus of this research is to understand the links between innovation, technical progress, and economic growth and to study the best industrial policies to improve economic growth and welfare in the U.S. Specifically, this research focuses on three major components of innovation and economic growth: (i) inventors, (ii) firms, and (iii) ideas (patents). The first part of this project examines the golden age of American innovation by undertaking a major data matching exercise linking U.S. patent records with data from Federal Censuses between 1880 and 1940 as a guide to the future. Then it studies the relationship between patented inventions and long-run economic growth, and outlines a framework for analyzing key macro- and micro-level determinants of innovativeness and growth. Over the last several decades economy-wide startup rates have declined in excess of twelve percent, while measures of factor reallocation and dispersion in firm growth rates have declined in excess of twenty percent. The second part of the project studies these changes in the U.S. economy. This part of the project focuses on understanding patterns of growth and innovation in the U.S. economy and ties together various empirical regularities using micro data from the U.S. economy. The goal is to understand the reasons for these changes and propose policies that can reconstruct entrepreneurship and job creation. The third part of this project studies the market for patents. How do non-practicing entities (NPEs) impact innovation and technological progress? This project provides new theoretical and empirical evidence on the subject.  In doing so the project informs the debate that has portrayed NPEs alternatively as benign middlemen that help to reallocate intellectual property to where it is most productive or stick-up artists that exploit the patent system to extract rents, thereby hurting innovation. As part of the project, the PI also plans to prepare a comprehensive set of online education materials on economic growth that will be freely accessible to everyone. The goal is to disseminate high-quality, but free materials to a broad range of students, including those who did not get the chance to study at a top institution.  The results of this research will contribute to economic growth, job creation and competitiveness of the U.S. economy.

Our understanding of macroeconomic growth and technological progress can be significantly improved by combining micro and macro perspectives. A macroeconomy is made of lots of micro firms that hire inventors to produce new innovative ideas. Therefore, this proposal--by focusing on the microeconomics of ideas, inventors, and firm behavior--aims to shed light on macroeconomic growth by capturing the rich heterogeneity in innovation behavior at the firm level by using the wealth of information on innovation and firm behavior. In addition, formal models allow us to make verbal notions operational and confront them with data. Therefore, this proposal also focuses on combining general equilibrium growth theories with rich micro data on millions of U.S. patents, inventors, and firms. By also using structural estimation techniques, this proposal will allow the PI not only to understand the underlying mechanisms, but also to do counterfactual policy exercises where the PI can study optimal industrial policy design.

por.por_cntn:
Technological progress and innovation serve as vital catalysts for economic growth. The main focus of this research project has been to understand the exact links between innovation and economic growth and to study the optimal industrial policies to bolster economic growth and welfare. Central to this study are three essential components pivotal to innovation and economic growth: (i) firms, (ii) inventors, and (iii) ideas (patents). By focusing on these elements, we tried to gain valuable insights into the mechanisms that drive innovation-led economic growth.

In the first part, our research examined the phenomenon of productivity slowdown in the US economy with a specific focus on firms. We observed dramatic changes in firm dynamics over the past few decades, including declining startup rates and a decrease in factor reallocation and dispersion in firm growth rates. Through empirical analysis, documented in Akcigit and Ates (2021), we summarized significant trends in the literature and proposed a comprehensive framework to interpret these observations. In Akcigit and Ates (2023), we employed economic theory and computational methods to evaluate potential explanations for the slowing US business dynamism. Notably, our findings highlighted the decline in knowledge diffusion from market leaders to followers as a prominent factor contributing to the observed trends.

We also explored the optimal design of corporate taxation and R&D policies to rejuvenate innovation and economic growth. In Akcigit and Stantcheva (2022) and Akcigit, Hanley, and Stantcheva (2022), we examined the interplay between corporate taxation, R&D incentives, and their impact on innovation. Moreover, in Akcigit, Hanley, Serrano-Velarde (2021), we investigated the role of universities in fostering economic growth, differentiating between basic and applied research investments. Our findings underscored the significance of policies that focus on public basic research and its synergy with the private sector.

Expanding our research beyond advanced economies, in Akcigit, Alp, and Peters (2021), we explored the role of managerial delegation in firm performance. By examining the delegation of managerial tasks and its implications for firm growth in developing countries, we shed light on potential explanations for the small size of firms in such economies and its aggregate consequences.

Addressing the contentious topic of foreign corporate investments in Silicon Valley, we examined their theoretical and empirical implications in Akcigit, Ates, Lerner, Townsend, Zhestkova (2023). Through comprehensive analysis of non-U.S. corporate investments in U.S. startups spanning several decades, we uncovered evidence supporting the presence of knowledge spillovers to foreign investors. While recognizing the benefits of such inbound investments for U.S. firms, we also explored the optimal government policies that strike a balance between facilitating investments and raising their costs.

In the second part, we shifted our focus to individuals. We investigated the impact of inventions on wage returns and employment outcomes for coworkers in Aghion, Akcigit, Hyytinen and Toivanen (2023). Additionally, in Akcigit, Dinlersoz, Greenwood, and Penciakova (2022), we explored the contributions of venture capitalists to startup entrepreneurs in the U.S. economy. Through rigorous analysis, we found that VC-backed startups exhibited higher early growth rates and initial patent quality, with outcomes being influenced by the experience level of venture capitalists.

We also delved into the role of human interaction for innovation in Akcigit, Caicedo, Miguelez, Stantcheva, and Sterzi (2018). Our research uncovered empirical facts about inventors' productivity, research teams, and collaborations, highlighting the significance of interactions with other inventors and their subsequent impact on productivity.

In the third part, we turned our attention to ideas and patents, studying the determinants of radical innovations in Acemoglu, Akcigit and Celik (2022). Our investigation revealed that firms that are more receptive to hiring younger managers are more likely to engage in radical innovations. In Akcigit, Grigsby, Nicholas, and Stantcheva (2022), we examined the effect of corporate and personal taxes on innovation in the United States over the twentieth century. Through detailed analysis, we uncovered how taxes affect the quantity and location of innovation. Finally, in Abrams, Akcigit, Oz, and Pearce (2019), we explored the role of "Patent Trolls" (NPE) in innovation and technological progress, providing valuable insights into their impact on downstream innovation.

I express my sincere gratitude to the numerous research assistants whose contributions have been instrumental in the success of these projects. Their involvement as research assistants has provided them with important exposure to cutting-edge research methodologies and techniques. Furthermore, I have been honored to deliver numerous seminars worldwide, showcasing these projects to esteemed institutions.

I am sincerely grateful for the generous support extended by the NSF, which has enabled the publication of nearly all of these impactful papers in top academic journals. Furthermore, the prestigious CAREER grant has provided me with the opportunity to push the boundaries of knowledge, share the findings to the broader community, fostering dialogue, and driving further advancements in the field of innovation, competition, and economic growth.
